htmlEmbed:
Heat wave map: See where Americans face the most extreme heat riskJohn Muyskens, Andrew Tran, Anna Phillips, Simon Ducroquet, Naema Ahmed7/15/2022

Explore our zip code level extreme heat map of the United States to see how heat waves and dangerous temperatures will affect your city in the coming years.

ArchivedRead

	(function (containerId, opts) {
		if (!("querySelector" in document)) return;
		var container = document.getElementById(containerId);
		var nameSpace = opts.namespace || '';
		var onResize = throttle(update, 200);
		var waiting = !!window.IntersectionObserver;
		var observer;
		update();

		document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", update);
		window.addEventListener("resize", onResize);

		// NYT Scoop-specific code
		if (opts.setup) {
			opts.setup(container).on('cleanup', cleanup);
		}

		function cleanup() {
			document.removeEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", update);
			window.removeEventListener("resize", onResize);
			if (observer) observer.disconnect();
		}

		function update() {
			var artboards = selectChildren("." + nameSpace + "artboard[data-min-width]", container),
					width = Math.round(container.getBoundingClientRect().width);

			// Set artboard visibility based on container width
			artboards.forEach(function(el) {
				var minwidth = el.getAttribute("data-min-width"),
						maxwidth = el.getAttribute("data-max-width");
				if (+minwidth <= width && (+maxwidth >= width || maxwidth === null)) {
					if (!waiting) {
						selectChildren("." + nameSpace + "aiImg", el).forEach(updateImgSrc);
					}
					el.style.display = "block";
				} else {
					el.style.display = "none";
				}
			});

			// Initialize lazy loading on first call
			if (waiting && !observer) {
				if (elementInView(container)) {
					waiting = false;
					update();
				} else {
					observer = new IntersectionObserver(onIntersectionChange, {});
					observer.observe(container);
				}
			}
		}

		function elementInView(el) {
			var bounds = el.getBoundingClientRect();
			return bounds.top < window.innerHeight && bounds.bottom > 0;
		}

		// Replace blank placeholder image with actual image
		function updateImgSrc(img) {
			var src = img.getAttribute("data-src");
			if (src && img.getAttribute("src") != src) {
				img.setAttribute("src", src);
			}
		}

		function onIntersectionChange(entries) {
			if (entries.length && entries[0].isIntersecting) {
				waiting = false;
				observer.disconnect();
				observer = null;
				update();
			}
		}

		function selectChildren(selector, parent) {
			return parent ? Array.prototype.slice.call(parent.querySelectorAll(selector)) : [];
		}

		// based on underscore.js
		function throttle(func, wait) {
			var timeout = null, previous = 0;
			function run() {
					previous = Date.now();
					timeout = null;
					func();
			}
			return function() {
				var remaining = wait - (Date.now() - previous);
				if (remaining <= 0 || remaining > wait) {
					clearTimeout(timeout);

data-coral-notext="true"></span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="story relative"><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">It was the middle of July and already this summer had become a top contender for the hottest in Texas’s recorded history. In San Antonio, which by July would normally experience about three days of triple-digit heat, there had been <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/14/texas-oklahoma-heat-wave-plains/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">three dozen</a>. Houston, Waco and Austin were also seeing temperatures 5 to 8 degrees above normal. The state was roasting and Texans were using <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/11/texas-record-heat-ercot-power-grid/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">a record amount of electricity</a> to stay cool.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">New calculations suggest that, by the middle of this century, this record-breaking summer in Texas may look normal.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Across much of the United States, millions of people are expected to experience extreme temperatures more frequently and for longer periods of time — a threat that will grow as climate change worsens. The <a href="https://riskfactor.com/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">new data</a>, released Monday by the nonprofit First Street Foundation, calculates the heat risk facing each property in the contiguous United States over the next 30 years, the length of a typical mortgage, providing some of the most detailed nationwide estimates. It uses heat index, a measure of how hot it feels outside by including temperature and humidity.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">A Washington Post analysis of the group’s data found that today’s climate conditions have caused an estimated 46 percent of Americans to endure at least three consecutive days of 100-plus degree heat, on average, each year. Over the next 30 years, that will increase to 63 percent of the population.</p><div style="min-height:691px"></div><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Nowhere is the danger more widespread than in the South, where global warming is expected to deliver an average of 20 extra days of triple-digit heat per year. In some southern states, such as Texas and Florida, residents could see over 70 consecutive days with the heat index topping 100 degrees Fahrenheit.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">“We’re talking about taking summer, which is already hot, and expanding it for months,” said Jaime González, director of the Houston Healthy Cities program for the Nature Conservancy in Texas. “That’s going to cause all sorts of disruptions to everyday life.”</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">This data comes as more Americans are moving to some of the hottest parts of the United States. For more than a decade, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/after-stalling-during-the-recession-americans-are-again-moving-from-snowbelt-to-sunbelt-census-reports/2017/03/22/fd2bb2ca-0f39-11e7-9d5a-a83e627dc120_story.html?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">census data</a> has shown Sun Belt states like Arizona, Texas and Florida drawing in new residents, while Northeastern and Midwestern states are not.</p><div class="mw-lg ml-auto mr-auto ad--desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-lg mt-lg pt-md pb-md flex" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:transparent;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:-9px"><div class="dib flex divider gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:">Story continues below advertisement</div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">The larger pattern identified by First Street’s model suggests that people living in the South are likely to face some of the most dramatic changes over the next several decades. A <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/interactive/2022/wildfire-risk-map-us/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">previous analysis</a> found that the southern half of the country also faces the greatest risk of wildfire.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">First Street’s analysis of property level heat exposure is based on a combination of high-resolution measurements of surface temperature data, tree cover, impervious surfaces — like pavement and asphalt — and proximity to water. It incorporates global climate models from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and it relies on a moderate scenario in which global greenhouse gas emissions peak around 2040 and then slowly decline. If countries act more quickly, or fail to enact climate-friendly policies, the outcome could change.</p><div class="mb-md"><div class="pg-graphic fallback-available" data-fallback-image-url="https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/ai2html/FIRERISK/VEWMXZWH4VFD3NHMLO3LNEPVEE/2300-table.jpg?c=1660333444396">

</div><!-- Close fallback div --></div><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">The analysis found that Miami-Dade County in Florida will likely suffer the most extreme change. Whereas the county sees about 50 days of a heat index above 100 degrees, it is likely to have 91 broiling days by 2053.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">“We know we have a heat problem here. This is right in line with what we expect,” said Jane Gilbert, Miami-Dade’s <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2021/05/12/climate-urban-heat-miami/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">chief heat officer</a>.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Unlike the West and the Midwest, which have been scorched this year by extreme heat waves, South Florida has chronic exposure to high heat for months, Gilbert said. This drives up energy costs and endangers outdoor workers, homeless people and those who can’t afford to air-condition their homes all day. The county has designated May 1 through Oct. 31 as an official heat season and launched an awareness campaign targeting neighborhoods with the highest rates of heat-related hospitalization.</p><p class="font--body font-copy color-gray-darkest pb-md italic mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm ">[<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/02/summer-2022-climate-change-heat/?itid=lk_interstitial_enhanced-template" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Why summer in America is becoming longer, hotter and more dangerous</a>]</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Gilbert said having property-level heat projections could help county officials make the case for more tree-planting and painted rooftops that reduce the need for air conditioning.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">“If it’s truly good modeling, it’s extremely valuable to help us develop policies to require cooling,” she said.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Florida tops the states that will see the largest increase in days with a heat index over 100 degrees. But residents all along the Gulf Coast and Southeastern Atlantic are also expected to live through more weeks of dangerous heat because of muggy summertime conditions, low elevation and the Gulf of Mexico’s warm waters.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Even more severe temperatures are expected to hit a swath of the country stretching from northern Texas and Louisiana to Illinois and Indiana. Though the central United States is not typically thought of as bearing the brunt of summertime heat, First Street’s analysis found that tens of millions more people living in this region are likely to see a heat index above 125 degrees by mid-century. The group calls this area an “extreme heat belt.”</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Situated between the Appalachian and Rocky Mountains, this part of the country “almost forms a bowl that funnels humidity into the area, which drives up those ‘feels like’ temperatures,” said Jeremy Porter, chief research officer for First Street.</p><div class="mb-md"><div class="pg-graphic fallback-available" data-fallback-image-url="https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/ai2html/heat-factor/3PW5RTJOZJCHDACHKRFWXVQ75I/2300-above-125.jpg?c=1660333543605">

</div><!-- Close fallback div --></div><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">According to the National Weather Service, at a heat index of 125 degrees — which the agency classifies as an “extreme danger” day — heat stroke becomes “highly likely.” And although there is no set temperature threshold at which <a href="https://www.kare11.com/article/news/local/roads-buckling-twin-cities-extreme-heat/89-22aff606-5af1-413f-aa78-b6f6b6f23297?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">roads</a>, bridges and trains <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/20/heat-wave-road-railway-buckling/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">start to fail</a>, or <a href="https://www.fortworthtexas.gov/news/2022/7/water-main-breaks?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">water pipes break</a>, <a href="https://www.newsweek.com/heat-wave-forces-amtrak-slow-trains-fear-expanding-tracks-wires-1727394?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">recent examples</a> show that it doesn’t take a 125-degree day to overtax essential infrastructure.</p><p class="font--body font-copy color-gray-darkest pb-md italic mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm ">[<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/interactive/2021/climate-change-humidity/?itid=lk_interstitial_enhanced-template" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">What extreme heat does to the human body</a>]</p><h3 id="h-ZNXJM2KKZBCYLBBNUSANDONY3I" class="font--headline font-md3 pb-sm pt-lg mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm "><b>Unequal risk</b></h3><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Heat is the <a href="https://www.weather.gov/phi/heat?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">top weather-related killer</a> in the United States. But like other effects of climate change, it is felt unevenly. The poor, the elderly, very young children and people with certain chronic medical conditions are most at risk.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Treeless city neighborhoods, packed with buildings, parking lots and asphalt roads, absorb and retain more heat than areas with tree-lined streets and parks. Scientists call this the urban heat island effect. Nationwide, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/05/25/heat-inequality-climate-change/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">this pattern</a> reveals itself in city after city, concentrating heat in majority low-income Black and Latino neighborhoods that were designated as <a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/01/14/795961381/racist-housing-practices-from-the-1930s-linked-to-hotter-neighborhoods-today?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">risky investments</a> decades ago.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Today, about 64 percent of all Black people in the U.S. experience a dangerous heat wave, defined as more than three consecutive days of a heat index above 100 degrees. But that will increase to 79 percent in 30 years, making a population that is already more vulnerable to heat significantly more exposed.</p><div class="mb-md"><div class="pg-graphic fallback-available" data-fallback-image-url="https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/ai2html/FIRERISK/VEWMXZWH4VFD3NHMLO3LNEPVEE/2300-race.jpg?c=1660561639951">

            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">The Post also found that by the middle of this century, 71 percent of the poorest neighborhoods in the country will likely endure severe heat.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">Extreme heat will also make work more dangerous. Today, there are roughly 3.8 million people who work outdoors and experience at least one severe heat wave. In 30 years, that number will increase nearly 30 percent to 4.9 million.</p><div class="mw-lg ml-auto mr-auto ad--desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-lg mt-lg pt-md pb-md flex" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:transparent;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:-9px"><div class="dib flex divider gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:">Story continues below advertisement</div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div><div class="mw-lg ml-auto mr-auto ad--mobile"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-lg mt-lg pt-md pb-md flex" style="border-top-color:transparent;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:-9px"><div class="dib flex divider gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:">Story continues below advertisement</div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">In the Houston neighborhood of Gulfton, the shift to more days of dangerous temperatures and humidity would expose the area’s 45,000 residents — many of them recent immigrants from Afghanistan, Syria, and Central America — to unbearable levels of heat. The neighborhood has one park and few trees. Two years ago, when Houston officials worked with scientists and volunteers to map its heat island effect, <a href="https://harcresearch.maps.arcgis.com/apps/Cascade/index.html?appid=38b69c4eb5344033b7f9cb82ca4575b3&itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template" target="_blank">they discovered</a> parts of Gulfton were 17 degrees hotter in the afternoon than the coolest neighborhood they measured.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">González said that until recently, conversations about climate change in Houston were dominated by talk of flooding and sea level rise. The destruction unleashed by Hurricane Harvey in 2017 forced the city to confront the likelihood of intensifying storms. Now, this summer’s record-setting heat is forcing another shift in focus, he said.</p><p class="
            font--article-body
            font-copy
            color-gray-darkest
            pb-md
            mw-md ma-auto pr-sm pl-sm 
              
            ">“We’re getting a little bit of a preview of what it might look like if we don’t take more action,” González said.</p><div class="about-card-section card"><div class="mw-md pl-sm pr-sm ma-auto mb-md"><div class="b brad-2 shadow pt-sm pl-sm pr-sm"><h5 class="mb-xs font-xxs ">About this story</h5><p class="font--meta-text mb-xs ">The 2023 numbers in the analysis reflect the current climate. They are estimates based on 2014-2020 averages, and adjusted to include temperature and humidity projections from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s global climate model ensemble. Population estimates are based on the 2020 5-year American Community Survey census tract data. Regions and divisions were identified by the Census Bureau. Outdoor worker estimates are based on County Business Patterns from 2020 and include the sectors of agriculture, construction, and landscaping services.</p><p class="font--meta-text mb-xs pb-xs">Editing by Monica Ulmanu.</p></div></div></div></div></article></main><aside class="mt-xl mw-lg mr-auto ml-auto pb-md"><div class="mw-grid grid grid-cols-12 mr-auto ml-auto mt-md pl-md type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"_id":"3PW5RTJOZJCHDACHKRFWXVQ75I","content_elements":[{"_id":"REBANHW3BRDAPM3HXK34H5DHWM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575361},"content":"It was the middle of July and already this summer had become a top contender for the hottest in Texas\u0026#x2019;s recorded history. In San Antonio, which by July would normally experience about three days of triple-digit heat, there had been \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/14/texas-oklahoma-heat-wave-plains/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ethree dozen\u003c/a\u003e. Houston, Waco and Austin were also seeing temperatures 5 to 8 degrees above normal. The state was roasting and Texans were using \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/11/texas-record-heat-ercot-power-grid/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ea record amount of electricity\u003c/a\u003e to stay cool."},{"_id":"EQ62MO5JXRDMFMD3ASMTRRAVKI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575362},"content":"New calculations suggest that, by the middle of this century, this record-breaking summer in Texas may look normal."},{"_id":"VH2M7UJ4J5BF3CRXMGKFOL5WGM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660320076828},"content":"Across much of the United States, millions of people are expected to experience extreme temperatures more frequently and for longer periods of time \u0026#x2014; a threat that will grow as climate change worsens. The \u003ca href=\"https://riskfactor.com/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template\" target=\"_blank\"\u003enew data\u003c/a\u003e, released Monday by the nonprofit First Street Foundation, calculates the heat risk facing each property in the contiguous United States over the next 30 years, the length of a typical mortgage, providing some of the most detailed nationwide estimates. It uses heat index, a measure of how hot it feels outside by including temperature and humidity."},{"_id":"UXTSX4ZCYZCZROHIU3GV44IOGQ","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660320530733},"content":"A Washington Post analysis of the group\u0026#x2019;s data found that today\u0026#x2019;s climate conditions have caused an estimated 46 percent of Americans to endure at least three consecutive days of 100-plus degree heat, on average, each year. Over the next 30 years, that will increase to 63 percent of the population."},{"_id":"46N2HLEAZZERPLUZ75UFU74DJI","type":"raw_html","additional_properties":{"_id":"AJSGB5WRZNFOPA5E32RACFO5FE"},"content":"Map","props":{}},{"_id":"N6NXRGQ7CVCW7PUI7Z3XLCLDD4","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575365},"content":"Nowhere is the danger more widespread than in the South, where global warming is expected to deliver an average of 20 extra days of triple-digit heat per year. In some southern states, such as Texas and Florida, residents could see over 70 consecutive days with the heat index topping 100 degrees Fahrenheit."},{"_id":"GM5QLIOFCFCCLE7KLKXWDNZOUI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575366},"content":"\u0026#x201C;We\u0026#x2019;re talking about taking summer, which is already hot, and expanding it for months,\u0026#x201D; said Jaime Gonz\u0026#xE1;lez, director of the Houston Healthy Cities program for the Nature Conservancy in Texas. \u0026#x201C;That\u0026#x2019;s going to cause all sorts of disruptions to everyday life.\u0026#x201D;"},{"_id":"YEEGGF527RB7VOPJBCXLCM6E34","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660232075187},"content":"This data comes as more Americans are moving to some of the hottest parts of the United States. For more than a decade, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/after-stalling-during-the-recession-americans-are-again-moving-from-snowbelt-to-sunbelt-census-reports/2017/03/22/fd2bb2ca-0f39-11e7-9d5a-a83e627dc120_story.html?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ecensus data\u003c/a\u003e has shown Sun Belt states like Arizona, Texas and Florida drawing in new residents, while Northeastern and Midwestern states are not."},{"_id":"KKOB4DNIAZDGHC6YYSBZTS2AYE","type":"ad","subtype":"inline_ad","additional_properties":{"_id":"IJB2DYQGTNAPZLGCVSGIIXWGTQ"},"props":{"adCount":1}},{"_id":"NZY34JZD2JDBBOO6QZDWLDR364","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660223287541},"content":"The larger pattern identified by First Street\u0026#x2019;s model suggests that people living in the South are likely to face some of the most dramatic changes over the next several decades. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/interactive/2022/wildfire-risk-map-us/?itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eprevious analysis\u003c/a\u003e found that the southern half of the country also faces the greatest risk of wildfire."},{"_id":"3PFTHF5YOFBX7B3GF5RBAHIOSU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660322037765},"content":"First Street\u0026#x2019;s analysis of property level heat exposure is based on a combination of high-resolution measurements of surface temperature data, tree cover, impervious surfaces \u0026#x2014; like pavement and asphalt \u0026#x2014; and proximity to water. It incorporates global climate models from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and it relies on a moderate scenario in which global greenhouse gas emissions peak around 2040 and then slowly decline. If countries act more quickly, or fail to enact climate-friendly policies, the outcome could change."},{"_id":"g-table-box","type":"ai2html","subtype":"graphic","additional_properties":{"_id":"LOWOGBMORBFT3NLPCY42TCYND4"},"content":"\u003cdiv class=\"pg-graphic fallback-available\" The county has designated May 1 through Oct. 31 as an official heat season and launched an awareness campaign targeting neighborhoods with the highest rates of heat-related hospitalization."},{"_id":"YIOYMSLF6NGALGK3AVFI45R33U","type":"interstitial_link","additional_properties":{"_id":"TUPEDFEJT5CYDDXOSOSQ437NAI"},"content":"Why summer in America is becoming longer, hotter and more dangerous","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/07/02/summer-2022-climate-change-heat/"},{"_id":"TBBISAXGRZFQ7NZRILVYGIPAMQ","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660232075193},"content":"Gilbert said having property-level heat projections could help county officials make the case for more tree-planting and painted rooftops that reduce the need for air conditioning."},{"_id":"AD3XIREA5BHX5LQD3WRFVZSPEY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660232075194},"content":"\u0026#x201C;If it\u0026#x2019;s truly good modeling, it\u0026#x2019;s extremely valuable to help us develop policies to require cooling,\u0026#x201D; she said."},{"_id":"EJKQB5MAD5GADBJG4HRXS3CFAM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660326883142},"content":"Florida tops the states that will see the largest increase in days with a heat index over 100 degrees. neighborhoods in the country will likely endure severe heat."},{"_id":"MNLLPHFMFJDKNJHQUZGIXGLD6Q","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660232075208},"content":"Extreme heat will also make work more dangerous. Today, there are roughly 3.8 million people who work outdoors and experience at least one severe heat wave. In 30 years, that number will increase nearly 30 percent to 4.9 million."},{"_id":"D6PJ22IO35GPFLSK3S26K3YAPA","type":"ad","subtype":"inline_ad","additional_properties":{"_id":"RQ3F3RTSEZCVXGTQOZVCBNZACQ"},"props":{"adCount":2}},{"_id":"NYDV5FPGV5CHTOPQMRPA3AUXJI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575382},"content":"In the Houston neighborhood of Gulfton, the shift to more days of dangerous temperatures and humidity would expose the area\u0026#x2019;s 45,000 residents \u0026#x2014; many of them recent immigrants from Afghanistan, Syria, and Central America \u0026#x2014; to unbearable levels of heat. The neighborhood has one park and few trees. Two years ago, when Houston officials worked with scientists and volunteers to map its heat island effect, \u003ca href=\"https://harcresearch.maps.arcgis.com/apps/Cascade/index.html?appid=38b69c4eb5344033b7f9cb82ca4575b3\u0026amp;itid=lk_inline_enhanced-template\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ethey discovered\u003c/a\u003e parts of Gulfton were 17 degrees hotter in the afternoon than the coolest neighborhood they measured."},{"_id":"W6JGLV4XJNHM7OIBF7QCC7LW5U","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575383},"content":"Gonz\u0026#xE1;lez said that until recently, conversations about climate change in Houston were dominated by talk of flooding and sea level rise. The destruction unleashed by Hurricane Harvey in 2017 forced the city to confront the likelihood of intensifying storms. Now, this summer\u0026#x2019;s record-setting heat is forcing another shift in focus, he said."},{"_id":"3JFJYPFA5VGVTCLJIBGO47VOYU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660213575384},"content":"\u0026#x201C;We\u0026#x2019;re getting a little bit of a preview of what it might look like if we don\u0026#x2019;t take more action,\u0026#x201D; Gonz\u0026#xE1;lez said."},{"_id":"HRDF4MOY5JG5XIFHHS4VTJQQKU","type":"about","count":0,"content_elements":[{"_id":"KQNIHPJQTVAIXPQNJOVLHAD6GA","type":"header","level":4,"additional_properties":{"_id":1660150441687},"content":"About this story"},{"_id":"VZGBJ65DYFDGBD5QCDZMDQEYYY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660234372333},"content":"The 2023 numbers in the analysis reflect the current climate. They are estimates based on 2014-2020 averages, and adjusted to include temperature and humidity projections from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change\u0026#x2019;s global climate model ensemble. Population estimates are based on the 2020 5-year American Community Survey census tract data. Regions and divisions were identified by the Census Bureau. Outdoor worker estimates are based on County Business Patterns from 2020 and include the sectors of agriculture, construction, and landscaping services."},{"_id":"HRDF4MOY5JG5XIFHHS4VTJQQKU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"_id":1660269337400},"content":"Editing by Monica readabilityObject.title: Heat wave map: See where Americans face the most extreme heat risk
readabilityObject.content:
It was the middle of July and already this summer had become a top contender for the hottest in Texas’s recorded history. In San Antonio, which by July would normally experience about three days of triple-digit heat, there had been three dozen. Houston, Waco and Austin were also seeing temperatures 5 to 8 degrees above normal. The state was roasting and Texans were using a record amount of electricity to stay cool.

New calculations suggest that, by the middle of this century, this record-breaking summer in Texas may look normal.

Across much of the United States, millions of people are expected to experience extreme temperatures more frequently and for longer periods of time — a threat that will grow as climate change worsens. The new data, released Monday by the nonprofit First Street Foundation, calculates the heat risk facing each property in the contiguous United States over the next 30 years, the length of a typical mortgage, providing some of the most detailed nationwide estimates. It uses heat index, a measure of how hot it feels outside by including temperature and humidity.

A Washington Post analysis of the group’s data found that today’s climate conditions have caused an estimated 46 percent of Americans to endure at least three consecutive days of 100-plus degree heat, on average, each year. Over the next 30 years, that will increase to 63 percent of the population.

Nowhere is the danger more widespread than in the South, where global warming is expected to deliver an average of 20 extra days of triple-digit heat per year. In some southern states, such as Texas and Florida, residents could see over 70 consecutive days with the heat index topping 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

“We’re talking about taking summer, which is already hot, and expanding it for months,” said Jaime González, director of the Houston Healthy Cities program for the Nature Conservancy in Texas. “That’s going to cause all sorts of disruptions to everyday life.”

This data comes as more Americans are moving to some of the hottest parts of the United States. For more than a decade, census data has shown Sun Belt states like Arizona, Texas and Florida drawing in new residents, while Northeastern and Midwestern states are not.

The larger pattern identified by First Street’s model suggests that people living in the South are likely to face some of the most dramatic changes over the next several decades. A previous analysis found that the southern half of the country also faces the greatest risk of wildfire.

First Street’s analysis of property level heat exposure is based on a combination of high-resolution measurements of surface temperature data, tree cover, impervious surfaces — like pavement and asphalt — and proximity to water. It incorporates global climate models from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and it relies on a moderate scenario in which global greenhouse gas emissions peak around 2040 and then slowly decline. If countries act more quickly, or fail to enact climate-friendly policies, the outcome could change.

The analysis found that Miami-Dade County in Florida will likely suffer the most extreme change. Whereas the county sees about 50 days of a heat index above 100 degrees, it is likely to have 91 broiling days by 2053.

“We know we have a heat problem here. This is right in line with what we expect,” said Jane Gilbert, Miami-Dade’s chief heat officer.

Unlike the West and the Midwest, which have been scorched this year by extreme heat waves, South Florida has chronic exposure to high heat for months, Gilbert said. This drives up energy costs and endangers outdoor workers, homeless people and those who can’t afford to air-condition their homes all day. The county has designated May 1 through Oct. 31 as an official heat season and launched an awareness campaign targeting neighborhoods with the highest rates of heat-related hospitalization.

[Why summer in America is becoming longer, hotter and more dangerous]

Gilbert said having property-level heat projections could help county officials make the case for more tree-planting and painted rooftops that reduce the need for air conditioning.

“If it’s truly good modeling, it’s extremely valuable to help us develop policies to require cooling,” she said.

Florida tops the states that will see the largest increase in days with a heat index over 100 degrees. But residents all along the Gulf Coast and Southeastern Atlantic are also expected to live through more weeks of dangerous heat because of muggy summertime conditions, low elevation and the Gulf of Mexico’s warm waters.

Even more severe temperatures are expected to hit a swath of the country stretching from northern Texas and Louisiana to Illinois and Indiana. Though the central United States is not typically thought of as bearing the brunt of summertime heat, First Street’s analysis found that tens of millions more people living in this region are likely to see a heat index above 125 degrees by mid-century. The group calls this area an “extreme heat belt.”

Situated between the Appalachian and Rocky Mountains, this part of the country “almost forms a bowl that funnels humidity into the area, which drives up those ‘feels like’ temperatures,” said Jeremy Porter, chief research officer for First Street.

According to the National Weather Service, at a heat index of 125 degrees — which the agency classifies as an “extreme danger” day — heat stroke becomes “highly likely.” And although there is no set temperature threshold at which roads, bridges and trains start to fail, or water pipes break, recent examples show that it doesn’t take a 125-degree day to overtax essential infrastructure.

[What extreme heat does to the human body]

Unequal risk

Heat is the top weather-related killer in the United States. But like other effects of climate change, it is felt unevenly. The poor, the elderly, very young children and people with certain chronic medical conditions are most at risk.

Treeless city neighborhoods, packed with buildings, parking lots and asphalt roads, absorb and retain more heat than areas with tree-lined streets and parks. Scientists call this the urban heat island effect. Nationwide, this pattern reveals itself in city after city, concentrating heat in majority low-income Black and Latino neighborhoods that were designated as risky investments decades ago.

Today, about 64 percent of all Black people in the U.S. experience a dangerous heat wave, defined as more than three consecutive days of a heat index above 100 degrees. But that will increase to 79 percent in 30 years, making a population that is already more vulnerable to heat significantly more exposed.

The Post also found that by the middle of this century, 71 percent of the poorest neighborhoods in the country will likely endure severe heat.

Extreme heat will also make work more dangerous. Today, there are roughly 3.8 million people who work outdoors and experience at least one severe heat wave. In 30 years, that number will increase nearly 30 percent to 4.9 million.

In the Houston neighborhood of Gulfton, the shift to more days of dangerous temperatures and humidity would expose the area’s 45,000 residents — many of them recent immigrants from Afghanistan, Syria, and Central America — to unbearable levels of heat. The neighborhood has one park and few trees. Two years ago, when Houston officials worked with scientists and volunteers to map its heat island effect, they discovered parts of Gulfton were 17 degrees hotter in the afternoon than the coolest neighborhood they measured.

González said that until recently, conversations about climate change in Houston were dominated by talk of flooding and sea level rise. The destruction unleashed by Hurricane Harvey in 2017 forced the city to confront the likelihood of intensifying storms. Now, this summer’s record-setting heat is forcing another shift in focus, he said.

“We’re getting a little bit of a preview of what it might look like if we don’t take more action,” González said.

About this story

The 2023 numbers in the analysis reflect the current climate. They are estimates based on 2014-2020 averages, and adjusted to include temperature and humidity projections from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s global climate model ensemble. Population estimates are based on the 2020 5-year American Community Survey census tract data. Regions and divisions were identified by the Census Bureau. Outdoor worker estimates are based on County Business Patterns from 2020 and include the sectors of agriculture, construction, and landscaping services.

Editing by Monica Ulmanu.

The state was roasting and Texans were using a record amount of electricity to stay cool.New calculations suggest that, by the middle of this century, this record-breaking summer in Texas may look normal.Across much of the United States, millions of people are expected to experience extreme temperatures more frequently and for longer periods of time — a threat that will grow as climate change worsens. The new data, released Monday by the nonprofit First Street Foundation, calculates the heat risk facing each property in the contiguous United States over the next 30 years, the length of a typical mortgage, providing some of the most detailed nationwide estimates. It uses heat index, a measure of how hot it feels outside by including temperature and humidity.A Washington Post analysis of the group’s data found that today’s climate conditions have caused an estimated 46 percent of Americans to endure at least three consecutive days of 100-plus degree heat, on average, each year. Over the next 30 years, that will increase to 63 percent of the population.Nowhere is the danger more widespread than in the South, where global warming is expected to deliver an average of 20 extra days of triple-digit heat per year. In some southern states, such as Texas and Florida, residents could see over 70 consecutive days with the heat index topping 100 degrees Fahrenheit.“We’re talking about taking summer, which is already hot, and expanding it for months,” said Jaime González, director of the Houston Healthy Cities program for the Nature Conservancy in Texas. “That’s going to cause all sorts of disruptions to everyday life.”This data comes as more Americans are moving to some of the hottest parts of the United States. For more than a decade, census data has shown Sun Belt states like Arizona, Texas and Florida drawing in new residents, while Northeastern and Midwestern states are not.The larger pattern identified by First Street’s model suggests that people living in the South are likely to face some of the most dramatic changes over the next several decades. A previous analysis found that the southern half of the country also faces the greatest risk of wildfire.First Street’s analysis of property level heat exposure is based on a combination of high-resolution measurements of surface temperature data, tree cover, impervious surfaces — like pavement and asphalt — and proximity to water. It incorporates global climate models from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and it relies on a moderate scenario in which global greenhouse gas emissions peak around 2040 and then slowly decline. If countries act more quickly, or fail to enact climate-friendly policies, the outcome could change.The analysis found that Miami-Dade County in Florida will likely suffer the most extreme change. Whereas the county sees about 50 days of a heat index above 100 degrees, it is likely to have 91 broiling days by 2053.“We know we have a heat problem here. This is right in line with what we expect,” said Jane Gilbert, Miami-Dade’s chief heat officer.Unlike the West and the Midwest, which have been scorched this year by extreme heat waves, South Florida has chronic exposure to high heat for months, Gilbert said. This drives up energy costs and endangers outdoor workers, homeless people and those who can’t afford to air-condition their homes all day. The county has designated May 1 through Oct. 31 as an official heat season and launched an awareness campaign targeting neighborhoods with the highest rates of heat-related hospitalization.[Why summer in America is becoming longer, hotter and more dangerous]Gilbert said having property-level heat projections could help county officials make the case for more tree-planting and painted rooftops that reduce the need for air conditioning.“If it’s truly good modeling, it’s extremely valuable to help us develop policies to require cooling,” she said.Florida tops the states that will see the largest increase in days with a heat index over 100 degrees. But residents all along the Gulf Coast and Southeastern Atlantic are also expected to live through more weeks of dangerous heat because of muggy summertime conditions, low elevation and the Gulf of Mexico’s warm waters.Even more severe temperatures are expected to hit a swath of the country stretching from northern Texas and Louisiana to Illinois and Indiana. Though the central United States is not typically thought of as bearing the brunt of summertime heat, First Street’s analysis found that tens of millions more people living in this region are likely to see a heat index above 125 degrees by mid-century. The group calls this area an “extreme heat belt.”Situated between the Appalachian and Rocky Mountains, this part of the country “almost forms a bowl that funnels humidity into the area, which drives up those ‘feels like’ temperatures,” said Jeremy Porter, chief research officer for First Street.According to the National Weather Service, at a heat index of 125 degrees — which the agency classifies as an “extreme danger” day — heat stroke becomes “highly likely.” And although there is no set temperature threshold at which roads, bridges and trains start to fail, or water pipes break, recent examples show that it doesn’t take a 125-degree day to overtax essential infrastructure.[What extreme heat does to the human body]Unequal riskHeat is the top weather-related killer in the United States. But like other effects of climate change, it is felt unevenly. The poor, the elderly, very young children and people with certain chronic medical conditions are most at risk.Treeless city neighborhoods, packed with buildings, parking lots and asphalt roads, absorb and retain more heat than areas with tree-lined streets and parks. Scientists call this the urban heat island effect. Nationwide, this pattern reveals itself in city after city, concentrating heat in majority low-income Black and Latino neighborhoods that were designated as risky investments decades ago.Today, about 64 percent of all Black people in the U.S. experience a dangerous heat wave, defined as more than three consecutive days of a heat index above 100 degrees. But that will increase to 79 percent in 30 years, making a population that is already more vulnerable to heat significantly more exposed.The Post also found that by the middle of this century, 71 percent of the poorest neighborhoods in the country will likely endure severe heat.Extreme heat will also make work more dangerous. Today, there are roughly 3.8 million people who work outdoors and experience at least one severe heat wave. In 30 years, that number will increase nearly 30 percent to 4.9 million.In the Houston neighborhood of Gulfton, the shift to more days of dangerous temperatures and humidity would expose the area’s 45,000 residents — many of them recent immigrants from Afghanistan, Syria, and Central America — to unbearable levels of heat. The neighborhood has one park and few trees. Two years ago, when Houston officials worked with scientists and volunteers to map its heat island effect, they discovered parts of Gulfton were 17 degrees hotter in the afternoon than the coolest neighborhood they measured.González said that until recently, conversations about climate change in Houston were dominated by talk of flooding and sea level rise. The destruction unleashed by Hurricane Harvey in 2017 forced the city to confront the likelihood of intensifying storms. Now, this summer’s record-setting heat is forcing another shift in focus, he said.“We’re getting a little bit of a preview of what it might look like if we don’t take more action,” González said.About this storyThe 2023 numbers in the analysis reflect the current climate. They are estimates based on 2014-2020 averages, and adjusted to include temperature and humidity projections from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s global climate model ensemble. Population estimates are based on the 2020 5-year American Community Survey census tract data. Regions and divisions were identified by the Census Bureau. Outdoor worker estimates are based on County Business Patterns from 2020 and include the sectors of agriculture, construction, and landscaping services.Editing by Monica Ulmanu.
